lines.text: I only have sex with a guy for money.
Yeah, I know.
And two guys can't love each other.
Yeah.
Well, I don't know. I mean... I mean, for me, I could love someone even if I, you know, wasn't paid for it... I love you, and... you don't pay me.
Mike...
I really wanna kiss you, man... Well goodnight, man... I love you though... You know that... I do love you.
[last lines]
I'm a connoisseur of roads. I've been tasting roads my whole life. This road will never end. It probably goes all around the world.
I love you, and you don't pay me.

[First lines, mumbled to self, counting seconds, looking at pocket watch]
5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10...
[Coughs]

I always know where I am by the way that the road looks. Like I just know that I've been here before. I just know that I've been stuck here, like this one f**king time before, you know that? Yeah. There's not another road anywhere that looks like this road - I mean, exactly like this road. It's one kind of place. One of a kind... like someone's face...
[cracks neck]
like a f**ked up face.
It's when you start doing things for free, that you start to grow wings. Isn't that right, Mike.
What?
Wings, Michael. You grow wings, and become a fairy.
Scott. When you inherit your fortune, on your twenty-first birthday, let's see... how far away is this?
One week away, Bob, just one more week.
Let's not call ourselves robbers, but Diana's foresters. Gentlemen of the shade. Minions of the Moon. Men of good government.

[under his breath]
When I turn twenty-one, I don't want any more of this life. My mother and father will be surprised at the incredible change. It will impress them more when such a fuck-up like me turns good than if I had been a good son all along. All the past years I will think of as one big vacation. At least it wasn't as boring as schoolwork. All my bad behavior I'm going to throw away to pay my debt. I will change when everybody expects it the least.
Why, you wouldn't even look at a clock unless hours were lines of coke, dials looked like the signs of gay bars, or time itself was a fair hustler in black leather.
That guy. He was your real dad, Mike.
Don't fuck me in the head anymore man! I know the fucking truth! I know who my fucking real dad is!
Who?... Who?
Dick, you. Richard, you're my dad. I know that.
You know too much.
Look Mike, sandwiches!
This chick's living in a new car ad.
This is a nice home. Do you live here?... I don't blame you.
I've been tasting roads my whole life.
When you wake up, wipe the slugs off your face. Be ready for a new day!
luckiest number of all.
You know your Math.
It's more than math Mike, it's... imaculate perfection!
Are you not a coward? Answer that, and that goes double!
You're calling me a coward? You fat duck!
I'd give a thousand dollars to be able to run as fast as you can.
It'll never happen Bob.
This road never ends. It probably goes all around the world.
Walt.
Yeah, Mike?
You think, um, that you could spot me ten more dollars?
Ten dollars? What's the matter, you can't get it from your dad?
My dad and I don't get along too well, you know that Walt.
We're not getting along that well either now, are we?
No we don't get along too well... or else he wouldn't have gone out and drowned himself at Boxcar Canyon.
Again? He hit the water this time?
He survived the first time, this time...
Oh, God.
You're the only one I can ask, you know that Walt! Please! I'll owe you a date, how about that? I'll owe you a date. Pleeeeeeeease.
Oh God, tears crying, hold on. Here you go.
[slides money under the door]
Thanks!
Dude, if we can't steal from them going into the bar, Dude, we can get them coming out! See, Bob-dude?
Getting away from everything feels good.
Yeah, it does.
When I left home, the maid asked me where I was off to. I said "Wherever. Whatever. Have a nice day."
You had a maid. If I had a normal family, and a good up-bringing, then I would have been a well-adjusted person.
It depends on what you call normal.
Yeah, it does. Well, you know. Normal. Like a mom and a dad and a dog, and shit like that. Normal. Normal.
So, you didn't have a normal dog?
No, I didn't have a dog.
Didn't... or... didn't have a normal dad?
Didn't have a dog or a normal dad anyway, yeah. That's alright. I don't feel sorry for myself. I mean, I feel like I'm... I feel like I'm... you know... well-adjusted.
Hey man, did you get into that Sinead O'Connor concert last night?
To the Sinead? What?
You know, the chick with the bald head.
I've never been to a concert before, dude.

[in a coffee shop]
How'd we get home?
That German guy. Hans. He brought you downtown, you were passed out. He said he was heading to Portland, so I asked him for a ride.
For some reason I'm forgetting a German guy named Hans.
Well. You were sleeping.
How much do you make off me while I'm sleeping?
Just a ride, Mike. I don't make anything. What, you think that I sell your body while you are asleep?
Yeah.

[Scott stirs his coffee]
No, Mike. I'm on your side.

I'm the one who heard him cry out last night. He said "God, God, God..." three or four times. And when I got there I put my hand into the bed and felt his feet. And they were cold as stone. And I checked the rest of his body. And it too was as cold as stone...
But how could you see green if it was so dark you could not see your own hand?
I'm afraid if I shared your wine, I might catch this awful disease you appear to have. My jacket would grow little zippers all over it and my toes would have jingle bells on them like those there.

[shouting at rabbit on roadside]
Oooh-woo-woo-woo-woo-woo-woo! Where do you think you're running, man? We're stuck here together, you s**t!

I never thought I could be a real model, you know fashion-shit, cause I'm better at full body stuff It.8 okay so long as the photographer doesn't come on to you and expect something for no pay I'm trying to make a living, you know, and I like to be professional 'Course if the guy wants to pay me, then shit-yeah. Here I am for him. I'll sell my ass, I do it on the street all the time for cash. And I'll be on the cover of a book. It's when you start doing it for free that you start to grow wings, Right, Mike?
